turns.speaker: THIN MAN
turns.text: Did you hear me, lad?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: All right, all right -- here -- everything --

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: You're up!  You must be feeling better --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes...

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: How long did you travel?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Well it seems like a long time -- but it wasn't really.  It's rather hard to explain.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Is there a lot of illness?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Some.  But I mean we aren't all so... handsome.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: His curiosity is amazing.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Kalen will tire you out if you let him.  He's always been curious. His father was firm with him but... it's just his way.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Your husband is dead?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: He's gone to a better place.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: It's hard for me to imagine a better place.  Where I come from there's so much... frenzy.  Day and night.  It seems we're all running faster and faster...  ... All in identical bowler hats.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: You're not from beyond the valley.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What makes you say that?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: We don't have anything like this. Or the machine where Kalen found you.  And I doubt they do beyond the valley... Now where do you come from?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You might find the truth rather hard to understand.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Then you can speak slowly.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Oh, that explains everything.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I know it's hard to believe, but it's true.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: That machine --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Allowed me to travel from my time to yours.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: How long ago?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: More than 800,000 years.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Why would you do that?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: I might find the truth rather hard to understand?... Can you go back?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes.  Or forward into the future. I suppose I really should check on the machine, see that it hasn't been damaged...

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: I'll take you tomorrow... You must have seen a lot on your journey.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: For a time it was astounding.  I saw the years spinning by, I was in the years spinning by.  We made such advances.  I don't understand half of them.  There was a machine that talked to me and others that flew through the sky... We must have been incredible thinkers and artists --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Is he all right?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Just a dream.  You should sleep too.  You're still not well.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: I'm going to sit with Kalen.  Keep the fire burning if you can.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I will...

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: I'll take you to your machine tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Thank you...

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: You seem fascinated by the stars.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You can see so many here.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Don't then have stars where you come from?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Not like this... They don't seem so bright with all the city lights.  I never really noticed them much...

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Good night, then.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Mara, I had a strange dream last night.  I was here, walking through a forest very much like this, and then...

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Then you came to a desert and mountains...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: And you saw a shape ahead of you...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes!

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: We all have that dream.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: All of you?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Every night.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You share dreams?  That's incredible.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: We share everything.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: This is magnificent...

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: And this is your "work"?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: The mud carriers.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I can see Kalen's point.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Want to be a high climber now, do you?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What you need is an engineer.  If you set up a system of pulleys and counterweights, some basic block and tackle mechanism, you could to this a lot more easily.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: It's not supposed to be easy, it's supposed to be beautiful.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What's it all for?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I mean, why do you do it?  What purpose does it serve?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: It has no purpose.  It's just beautiful... Does everything have a purpose where you come from?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Most things.  We're very high on purpose.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: It's always been this way here.  We work on the towers all our lives. When we're young we train to be planners or climbers or sculptors...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Or mud carriers.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: And there's no shame to that.  It's all the same here.  Everyone has an important job to do.  We all work together and couldn't survive without each other.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What are you?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: I'm a planner.  I help decide where the new towers go and what they should look like.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: How do you decide?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: I try to imagine how they'll look when they're done.  I try to imagine how we'll fit in with them... our place in the world.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: ... It was a great city.  The greatest city in the world.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: You liked it there.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Oh, very much...  ... I used to work somewhere in that direction, I think.  A huge university where we taught everything from botany to history to literature.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Learning was important?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Oh very.  Learning, commerce, the arts -- the whole place was buzzing all the time.  Night and day.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Did you have fires at night?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Only to keep warm.  For illumination we had gaslights on most of the streets and a new invention called electrical lighting that made it seem like daylight all through the night.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: It must have been safe.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Oh, it was...  ... Most of the time.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: It sounds like a wonderful place to live.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Looking back... I suppose it was. I didn't quite realize it at the time but...

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Alexander...?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Orion's belt...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Those rocks, over there... they're the same... this is... Central Park.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: You know this?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Over there was Fifth Avenue -- and the Plaza Hotel was there... this is... the carriage path.  We're on the carriage path.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: This is where my journey started... right here.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: You lost someone.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Someone you loved very much.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes... After her death, it was intolerable for me here... The future had to be better.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Is it?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: If you only knew...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You've welcomed me into your home. Into your lives.  Everyone has... For the first time in a long time it doesn't hurt quite so much.  I thank you for that.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: I know what it is to lose someone. When my husband was taken from us... I thought the pain would never end.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Good -- it looks fine.  We had quite a ride together...

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: It's undamaged?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes... a little scorching on the upholstery but otherwise all ship- shape.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: So you can use it now?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes... I suppose so.

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Go back to your own time?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I could...

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Alexander, take my son away.  Take him back to your time.  Will you do that?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Mara --

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Please, I beg you.  Take him away from here --

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Kalen...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Mara...?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: No!

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Mara -- what -- ?!

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Kalen -- we have to get Kalen -- !

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: It was different then.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: My laboratory was about... here. And the kitchen was over there, where that tree is.  Mrs. Watchit wouldn't allow me in much... but, yes, this is about the kitchen.

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: Oh huzzah, the master's home.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Do you have it?!

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: Hello, Mr. Philby.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Don't torture me -- do you have it?

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: I have it, but don't you think for one moment I'll be letting you go out in that filthy coat -- now go upstairs and change.  I've laid out your green coat.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What's the matter with -- ?  -- What would I do without you, Mrs. Watchit?

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: Now that's more like it.  You look a proper gentlemen for once.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Then if Emma turns me down will you marry me?

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: Oh, I'm already swooning.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Ouch -- all right, wish me luck.

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: Sir, Mr. Philby is here.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Here?

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: Yes, sir, he --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Tell him to go away --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: All right, Mrs. Watchit.  You can go.

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: May I get you some --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: That'll be all.

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: Dr. Philby, Dr. Hartdegen.  I received the most extraordinary letter last week.  From a parent. We are always pleased to receive letters from parents.  They are our employers, after all.  This gentleman's son is in your class, Dr. Hartdegen.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: As I recall the syllabus the name of your tutorial is "Applied Mathematics and Engineering", am I correct?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Exactly correct, sir.

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: Well, just as I thought.  Surely it's all been a terrible mistake. This parent actually suggested that your freshman course in applied mathematics has somehow become a seminar on theoretical physics!

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Imagine that.

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: But I know that none of my faculty would ever deviate from the assigned curriculum.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Well... perhaps I have "deviated" the tiniest bit.

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: Might I ask why?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Because the assigned curriculum is boring.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Sir, that curriculum is forty years out of date.  The students today are looking toward the new century -- they want to be challenged and inspired, not spoon-fed dusty old equations that have been proved a thousand times.  They want to explore.

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: Do they?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: And roosters.

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: No, Dr. Hartdegen, they are not just chickens and roosters.  They are science.  Perhaps they aren't "inspiring" to you.  Perhaps they don't "challenge" you --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No, sir --

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: Animal husbandry is science, Dr. Hartdegen.  I have been breeding these fowl for fourteen years.  I have filled a library with information on their feeding patterns, social behavior and breeding.  Empirical, exacting, quantifiable records.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Sir --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: With respect, sir, would we have the telegraph without fantasy? Would we have radium and X-rays without someone first dreaming we could?

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: The advances you speak of were the result of countless years of study and empirical experimentation, a careful evolutionary process, not chalkboard parlor-tricks.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: My equations are not parlor-tricks!

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: Abstract mathematics, relativity of dimensions, geometrical "durations" -- even allowing for the uses of speculation, what is the point?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Because it's a new way of seeing the world!  Of seeing our place in it!

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: Very good.  Now if you will excuse us for a moment.

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: And hungry, I'd say.  You had such a long journey.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I did...

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: Well, we're happy you're here. Come inside.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: "Eloi"?

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: What are your people called?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Well, I guess you'd call us... New Yorkers.

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: New Yorkers.

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: We had another visitor from beyond the valley about four years ago. His name was Moren.  Do you know him?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: He said he traveled for two months.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I took a different route.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Oh, very different.  But not entirely... I mean we have lots of, um, trees and such.  But not everywhere.  And more roads.  And buildings.

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: To live in.  There's a lot of us... beyond the valley.

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: New Yorkers.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes.  I hope you won't take this the wrong way but is there someone older I could talk to?  An elder or patriarch of some kind?

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: I am the oldest.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No, I mean someone considerably older.  Your father perhaps?

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: My father has gone to a better place.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to...

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: Of course.  You're just tired. Mara, will you look after Alexander tonight?

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: Good morning, Alexander.  Feeling up to some work?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I suppose so.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Where do they take them?!

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: We don't know.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: We have to go after them, find where -- !

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: Alexander, I know you're trying to help.  But they don't come back.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What do you mean?!

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: They've gone to a better place.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You know that's not true.

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: We choose to believe it.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: My God!  How can you just do nothing!?  They're your friends, your family.  You all knew Mara. You ate with her and worked with her... Your work in the valley, what is that for if not to --

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: This is out life, Alexander.  It's a hard life but it is how we have always lived.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Then it's time to change that --

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: We are what we are.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You won't even try?

turns.speaker: KORUS
turns.text: We can't change the day and the night, Alexander.  This is the world.

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: My fowl have polluted the yard.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Dean Fulton...

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Sir, if I may --

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: Young man, we have a way of doing things here.  Radical theorizing is not acceptable.  Have I made myself understood?

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: If I might explain, sir --

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: You supported his application, Dr. Philby.  You are his senior, advisor.  I depend upon you to restrain his... excesses.  Any repetition of the behavior I witnessed in his classroom today and there will be consequences for you both.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DEAN FULTON
turns.text: Now you are upsetting my fowl. Please go.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: How did you get hurt?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Kalen...

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: I found you.  I saved your life. You were bleeding all over the place!

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: That's quite enough, Kalen.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: What did you do at night?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: What's it like where you come from?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: We'll see about that.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: I am.  Are you a climber?

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: I want to see your home.  Will you take me?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Kalen, right now you need to go up to bed.  You're exhausting Alexander.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: You'll tell me more tomorrow?

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Kalen, it's all right, I'm here --

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: They're here!  They're inside the house -- !

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: No, you're safe --

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: They're inside --

turns.speaker: MARA
turns.text: Kalen, look at me.  There's no one here but us.  You see... I'm here, you're here, Alexander's here. There are no Morlocks.  It was just a dream...

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Hello, Mrs. Watchit.  You're looking in the pink.

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: Must be all the exercise I get scampering up and down these stairs like a wee lamb.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: I wonder if that poor girl has any idea what she's in for?

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: For our sake, I hope not.

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: I don't know what to tell you, sir. He's been gone this whole week.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: And you've no idea where he went?

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: Sir?

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: I'm glad he's gone.  Maybe he's finally found a place where he can be happy.

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: I think I might be.  But there'll be some changes made.  I run a tight house.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: I have no doubt of that.  I'll come by in the morning and we'll arrange it.  Goodnight, Mrs. Watchit.

turns.speaker: MRS. WATCHIT
turns.text: Goodnight, Mr. Philby.

turns.speaker: DR. GRIES
turns.text: You ok?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: DR. GRIES
turns.text: [Beat] Listen, I hate to bother you...

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Then don't.

turns.speaker: DR. GRIES
turns.text: But... what about Starks?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: What about Starks?

turns.speaker: DR. GRIES
turns.text: Should we be...

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Should we be what? Trying to change him any way we can? [Beat] Yes.

turns.speaker: DR. GRIES
turns.text: But the Jacket? I mean...should we be leaving him in like that?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Don't get all worked up, Justin. I expected some common sense on your part and clearly I was expecting too much. [Beat] Just open the drawer.

turns.speaker: DR. GRIES
turns.text: We never should have done this to him...

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Well, what are we gonna do about it now?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Well, your condition's pretty serious.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: [Beat] So they say. [Off Becker's steady gaze] What?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: I'm just looking at you. Does that make you uncomfortable?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: Depends on what you're seeing.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: You said you couldn't remember killing Officer Harrison. Correct?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: [Beat] You don't believe me, do you?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: It's not my job to believe you.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: He's recovering on the third floor.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: Are you kidding me? He's not psychotic!

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Then how would you describe him, Beth? Merely rebellious?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: I don't know better. All I know is that you left me in there.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: In where?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: [Uncertainly] In that thing...the Jacket.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: We were forced to use restrains if that's what you're referring to.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: That wasn't a fucking restraint.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Actually, that's exactly what our equipment is.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Relax.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: Don't act like I don't know what's real. [Beat] I'm not the one that's crazy here.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: [Pointedly] Of course you're not.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: You're just suffering from delusions that are unfortunately part of your condition.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: Don't give me that. I know what's real, goddamnit! You strapped me in something and stuck me in a drawer.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: I didn't dream it. I may have been asleep but it wasn't a dream. BECKER sits down in a CHAIR, half-shrouded in the light.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: I had a patient a few years ago. His name was Ted Casey...

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: I don't give a shit about your patient!

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: I wasn't pausing to see if you did. [Beat] But, incidentally, you should, because you're birds of a feather.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: We are not birds of a feather.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Maybe not. [Beat] But I do think you're in a tree... woofing like a dog. And I'm just trying to help you the only way I can think of.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: Long live the Organization for the Organized!

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Sit down, Mr. Starks! Sit down, Mr. Starks!

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Hello, William. I understand you've been asking for me almost every hour. I would've been here sooner but you gave our little state visitor quite a bit to talk to me about.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: That's too bad.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: It is. But when it comes down to it, you just have to patient with them. They'd rather have their vacation, too, so they just push dealing with our "practices" off to the New Year.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: They make it hard for you to get away with your business, huh?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Temporarily.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: And what's that?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: My business?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: Getting away with things. Like whatever I may or may not have gotten away with Officer Harrison.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: You killed him?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: I'll say a prayer for you in Church today, Starks. Maybe the Gods can pick up where the medicine left off.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: You sure you know where to find one?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: I've managed to every Sunday of my life. [Beat] Some of us are God- fearing men, Starks.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: And what does that mean?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Means we believe in doing his work and fear what the world would be like if we didn't at least try to.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: Becker, how do you sleep at night?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: You in here. [Beat] Works like a drug.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: I think you know. Your eyes say you do.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: [Beat] You're his son?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: No. I'm not his son. I'm him. [Beat] What? You look like you've seen a ghost. You can come here and touch me, old man. I'm the real thing.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: How...how are you here?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: You died, Starks. Years ago, in the hospital.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: I know. [Beat] You killed me, didn't you?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: No. I didn't. I swear I didn't. I probably helped push you to kill yourself, but I didn't do it.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: I didn't kill myself. I died from a blow to the head. How'd it happen? I have to know.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: I don't know how you died. The last time I put you in the Jacket was just after you told me you remembered killing that police officer...

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: I didn't say I remembered killing him. I just repeated some words to get myself back in there.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: I know. [Beat] I knew that when you came out.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Because...because you came out and said something you couldn't have possibly have known. You came back and repeated three names...

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: Of people like you. People I was just trying to help. They couldn't get worse so I thought, with medication, they might get...

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: Medication? What kind of meds do you chase with nights in a cadaver drawer?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: It was part of the treatment I intended...I didn't know what the effects would be...

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: So, what, you guinea pig sick people to find out?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: The three of you weren't regular patients. You were criminals that ended up at Alpine Grove.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: No, we were patients.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: How did you come to know their names?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: You just told me. The last time I was with you was when I was in the Jacket. I'm in it right now, Dr. Becker.

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: I don't understand...

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: I'm in it as we speak. [Beat] You're haunting yourself right now. [Beat] I guess sometimes we indict ourselves if no one else does. You didn't make history like you wanted to, huh, Dr. Becker. It turned out different, didn't it?

turns.speaker: BECKER
turns.text: I didn't put you in Alpine Grove.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: No. [Beat] You put me on drugs and then you put me in the Jacket.

turns.speaker: DAMON
turns.text: Do I know you from somewhere?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: You may have known my father, William Starks.

turns.speaker: DAMON
turns.text: That's right! Goddamn, you're the spitting image. I didn't know he had a son.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: He didn't either.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: Did you know my father?

turns.speaker: DAMON
turns.text: Oh yeah, sure. He killed a cop, right?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: My father used to talk about you.

turns.speaker: DAMON
turns.text: Oh yeah, what'd he say?

turns.speaker: DAMON
turns.text: Look here, I don't like you getting in my face and saying this bullshit to me...

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: That's too bad.

turns.speaker: DAMON
turns.text: I thought you said you never knew your father.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: I didn't. [Beat] Did you have anything to do with his death?

turns.speaker: DAMON
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about, man. I swear. This is some weird shit you're telling me... and I don't know how come you're doing it.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: He died because he bled to death from a blow to his head. Someone had to have given him it.

turns.speaker: DAMON
turns.text: I never touched your father! I swear!

turns.speaker: DR. GRIES
turns.text: We're late.

turns.speaker: LORENSON
turns.text: I wish they'd skip the formality of this annual review and just cut our budget. Our silence on the matter should be enough to appease the civic conscience without wasting an hour we don't have.

turns.speaker: DR. GRIES
turns.text: Maybe it's not such a waste.

turns.speaker: LORENSON
turns.text: It's the ticking of a box on a sheet of paper no one cares about.

turns.speaker: DR. GRIES
turns.text: They don't care about all the things we do right. [Beat] But they might ...they might care about what we're doing wrong. [Beat] That's what they should come here to look for.

turns.speaker: LORENSON
turns.text: What should they be looking for?

turns.speaker: DR. GRIES
turns.text: They should just be looking harder.

turns.speaker: LORENSON
turns.text: Where? [Beat] It's Becker isn't it? He's doing stuff, isn't he?

turns.speaker: DR. GRIES
turns.text: Later. I'll tell you about it later. We got a session to catch now.

turns.speaker: DR. LORENSON
turns.text: You look like you've lost some weight. Are you eating?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: I am. One of the few things I remember doing is eating. So I guess I must be exercising it off in my dreams.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: You done with your small talk?

turns.speaker: DR. LORENSON
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: This is really happening, isn't it?

turns.speaker: DR. LORENSON
turns.text: [Beat] What do you need me to do?

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: [Beat] Thank you.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: I need to get this letter to someone.

turns.speaker: DR. LORENSON
turns.text: I can't take you out of here in your condition...

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: And I can't stay here in my condition. I am going to die tonight. It's already been decided.

turns.speaker: DR. LORENSON
turns.text: No, it hasn't.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: Yes. [Beat] It has. Everything up 'till today is done. Everything starting with tomorrow is up for grabs.

turns.speaker: DR. MORGAN
turns.text: I'm sorry I can't tell you more about your father's death, Mr. Starks. Our own medical examiners determined only that he died from a blunt trauma to the head but that was right around the time the Alpine Grove's staff changed and I'm afraid we didn't have the best record system before then.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: His body was found on January 1, 1993, but do you know if that was long after he had died?

turns.speaker: DR. MORGAN
turns.text: No, I don't. I'm sorry. I wish I knew more.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: What about Dr. Thomas Becker or Dr. Loel Lorenson? There was also a Dr. Gries, I think.

turns.speaker: DR. MORGAN
turns.text: Well, Dr. Lorenson is still here at the hospital. If she was here at the time your father was, then I'm sure she'd be of more help to you.

turns.speaker: STARKS
turns.text: What about Dr. Becker and Mr. Gries?

turns.speaker: DR. MORGAN
turns.text: Unfortunately, I'm not familiar with Dr. Becker and Dr. Gries passed away three, four years ago.

turns.speaker: JEAN
turns.text: Get your fucking hands off my daughter!

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Mom, he just fixed our car.

turns.speaker: JEAN
turns.text: Jackie, get in the car. NOW!
